bibl.title: Letter from Helen Wheeler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 19, 1941

div1.p: Wheeler writes that she has received the yellow fever material sent by Hench and will look for the additional materials he requested. She informs him of the location of the Lazear memorial tablet at Johns Hopkins University.

div1.head: Letter from Helen Wheeler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 19, 1941
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
WELCH MEDICAL LIBRARY
1900 EAST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD.
September 19, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am sorry to have been so slow in replying to your letter
of August 28th. It arrived just as I returned from a month's vacation
to face an accumulation of matters demanding attention.

The yellow fever material arrived in good shape, and I want
to thank you also for the copy of your interesting address at the
unveiling of Cornwell's painting. We are very glad indeed to have the
additional information you are unearthing about the yellow fever experi-
ments, and are quite willing to leave the matter in your hands. I hope
Dr. Peabody has the missing letters.

The tablet to Dr. Lazear, formerly in the medical or surgical
amphitheater, is now in the long corridor which connects the various
hospital buildings. The date of his death is given correctly as Septem-
ber 25, 1900, although in the copy (not photographic) of the tablet as
given in Dr. Kelly's book the date is September 28th.

I am sorry I have not yet had an opportunity to look up the
photographs from Dr. Kelly's collection which you want, but will try to
do so in a few days, and will gladly send you any relevant material we
may find.

Thank you again for your own contributions to our yellow
fever collection.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Helen Wheeler
For the Librarian HW
